section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to introduce the book and identify it as a narrative about facing our fears.
Use Circle Time to introduce vocabulary (edge).
Use Circle Time to review the letters Yy, Vv, and Qq.
Begin Story Time by asking the guiding question: How did Jabari feel about jumping off the diving board?
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize and produce words that have the same beginning sound.
Recognize at least 20 letter sounds.
Express opinion of abilities
Identify connections and differences between feelings and behavior.
Take initiative.
Respond appropriately to spoken language; Show understanding of spoken language.
Share observation about stories; Tell or retell stories.
Make connections between words and real life.
Master basic skills of running, jumping, climbing and pedaling.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Provide children with two words that start with the same sound.
Assess phonological knowledge by challenging children to produce a new word that begins with the same sound.
Encourage teamwork.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What can happen when we try something new?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Find a character in your book. What is the character’s name?
Can you pretend you are diving off a really high diving board?
Can you use the connecting cubes to build a diving board ladder? How many did you use?
Can you write about a time when you were scared?
Can you use these materials to make a swimming pool?
Can you draw a picture of something that begins with the letter Y?
Can you build a diving board?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder and introduce vocabulary (ready, scared).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Jabari Jumps.
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize and produce words that have the same beginning sound.
Relate own experiences to those in books.
Express opinion of abilities
Show self-awareness in different/multiple ways
Identify emotions in self
Reframe the narrative in order to persist and self-motivate.
Respond appropriately to spoken language; Show understanding of spoken language.
Share observation about stories; Tell or retell stories.
Make connections between words and real life; Understand shades of meaning among verbs.
Use art for self-expression.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Enrich children’s emotional skills by developing self-awareness.
Challenge children to name their own strengths, weaknesses, and fears.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What can happen when we try something new?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What is the character in your book good at?
Can you act out something you’re good at doing?
Name three things you want to be better at.
Can you write about a time when you faced your fear?
Can you use these materials to make something you’re good at?
Draw a picture of something that begins with the letter V?
Can you build the pool where Jabari, Jabari’s dad, and Jabari’s sister are?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Jabari Jumps by Gaia Cornwall. Copyright © 2017 by Gaia Cornwall. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Candlewick Press. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension strategy Make a Connection and teach new vocabulary (spread).
Start Story Time by revisiting Jabari Jumps and asking the guiding question: How do we know Jabari is scared of jumping off the diving board?
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize and produce words that have the same beginning sound.
Revise and edit group writing; Compose a narrative; Contribute ideas and participate in group writing.
Express opinion of abilities.
Take initiative.
Share observation about stories; Tell or retell stories.
Make connections between words and real life; Understand shades of meaning among verbs.
Master basic skills of running, jumping, climbing, and pedaling.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Empower children to take initiative in creating their own story.
Challenge children to tell a story, based on narratives having a beginning, middle, and end.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What can happen when we try something new?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How is this story like Jabari Jumps?
Can you pretend you are swimming underwater?
Can you draw the swimming pool? What shape did you draw?
Can you write more of the story we wrote together in our small group?
Can you use these materials to create a character from the story we wrote together?
Can you draw a picture of something that begins with the letter Q?
Can you build one place where the story we wrote together took place?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Jabari Jumps by Gaia Cornwall. Copyright © 2017 by Gaia Cornwall. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Candlewick Press.

tg_materials-caption.tg_materials-caption_book-title-Ital: Big Chart of Big Ideas: I Like to Race

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about persistence and introduce vocabulary (stretch, race).
Start story time by connecting the texts Jabari Jumps and I Like to Race.
Read closely to answer the weekly concept question: What can happen when we try something new?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize and produce words that have the same beginning sound.
Write uppercase and lowercase letters.
Take initiative.
Respond appropriately to spoken language; Show understanding of spoken language.
Share observation about stories.
Make connections between words and real life; Understand shades of meaning among verbs.
Master basic skills of running, jumping, climbing, and pedaling.
Expermiment with a variety of fine-motor tasks but may lack strength and control.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Review the alphabet with children.
Have children practice consecutive letter order.
Encourage children to have healthy feelings about competition.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What can happen when we try new things?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How is the character in this book like the boy in I Like to Race?
Pretend you are training for a race! What kind of race is it?
How many can you name? Can you show me?
Can you write a story about being in a race? What kind of race is it?
Can you make the boy’s racing wheelchair out of these materials?
Can you find words that start with Y in Yellow Yaks? Can you read them?
Can you build a racetrack for the boy?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Jabari Jumps by Gaia Cornwall. Copyright © 2017 by Gaia Cornwall. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Candlewick Press.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Photos © Shutterstock: salt (Chones), tray (Konstantin Faraktinov).

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to actively engage children and introduce new vocabulary (bottom).
Start Story Time by revisiting Jabari Jumps and asking the guiding question: How are you like Jabari?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize and produce words that have the same beginning sound.
Share and repeat the details in a text.
Express an opinion.
Express opinion of abilities.
Share observation about stories; Tell or retell stories.
Make connections between words and real life; Understand shades of meaning among verbs.
Master basic skills of running, jumping, climbing, and pedaling.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: What is a new thing you would like to try?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s work to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What can happen when we try new things?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you imagine this story with a different ending?
Can you pretend you are doing something you have never tried?
Can you count how many different tries Jabari takes before he finally jumps?
Can you write a story about trying something that scared you at first?
Can you use these materials to make something you’d like to try, like flying a plane or eating a new food?
Can you read an Alphabet Book to a stuffed animal?
Can you build a place you’d like to go that you’ve never been before? What will you build?

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Can produce a word that begins with the same sound as a given pair of words.
Recognize at least 20 distinct letter sounds in the language of instruction.
Show initiative in independent situations and persist in attempting to solve problems.
Initiate problem-solving strategies and seek adult help when necessary.
Show understanding by responding appropriately.
Show understanding of the language being spoken by teachers and peers.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Can produce a word that begins with the same sound as a given pair of words.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Show a reasonable opinion of own abilities and limitations.
Show understanding by responding appropriately.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Use art as a form of creative self-expression and representation.
Can produce a word that begins with the same sound as a given pair of words.
Interact and provide suggestions to revise (add, take out, change order) and edit (conventions) class-made drafts.
Show a reasonable opinion of own abilities and limitations.
Show initiative in independent situations and persist in attempting to solve problems.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Demonstrate coordination and balance in isolation.
Can produce a word that begins with the same sound as a given pair of words.
Show initiative in independent situations and persist in attempting to solve problems.
Initiate problem-solving strategies and seek adult help when necessary.
Show understanding of the language being spoken by teachers and peers.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Demonstrate coordination and balance in isolation (may not yet coordinate consistently with a partner).
Show control of tasks that require small-muscle strength and control.
Can produce a word that begins with the same sound as a given pair of words.
Retell or reenact a story after it is read aloud.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
Show a reasonable opinion of own abilities and limitations.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Demonstrate coordination and balance in isolation (may not yet coordinate consistently with a partner).
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
